Half of business software is even older than that: the mainframe crap saved from Y2K. Take a moment for it to sink in. The original creators of that software never expected it to linger that long and live past year 2000, hence they didn’t allocate the precious (at the time) two additional digits for the year. “Averting” Y2K was a huge step backward - akin (sorry, steampunk fans) saving steam (or carburetor) engines in a similar manner.Did IT try to replace COBOL and the rest of that stuff with newer technology? It did and failed. The infamous IT (meaning outside of Googles and Facebooks) project failure rate of 70% started to manifest itself in the late 90s during those attempts. The technology was no longer adequate to tame the runaway business process complexity - regardless of the project budget and headcount, which predictably made things way worse.Larry Ellison’s invention: related tables of data coupled with old-school procedural programming (the only one available at the time, not to mention the flat two-dimension data nature - inherently foreign to OOP and other modern programming paradigms) doesn’t scale well complexity-wise. Imagine doing even a moderate enterprise system in Excel with VBA macros, etc. Or Access for that matter. Yes, it’s possible. Just extremely inefficient - like an army of slaves building an Egyptian pyramid vs. a relatively lean team of modern construction professionals operating robust machines.Google’s, Facebook’s, and Netflix’s niches are different: consumer. Yes, they’ve invented a lot and donated it to the open-source community, but their products/services are still 100% consumer. Mighty Google won’t touch targeted (meaning always custom) enterprise software with a 10ft pole. Not cool enough, but more importantly very complex domain-wise - way outside of an average “algorithmic” techie attention span.What happened? An 18-year (since the Y2K) if not longer enterprise technology stagnation. Why it happened? I gave you a hint, recalling the Egyptian pyramids. Ever since the dawn of our technology-driven civilization it is the shortage of labor, that led to inventions to automate something. The surplus of cheap labor (found in a few well-known overpopulated countries) halts, and in some cases (pre-Y2K 1960s-70s crap) reverses the technical progress.How long that stagnation will last? For another 10 years, until everything saved from Y2K will crash and burn, as it was not very robust to begin with, let alone five bugs an average “outsourced” code monkey makes by fixing one - supporting that crap. The real Y2K was just postponed until 2030s. I am talking about major banks, hospitals, and the rest of Fortune 1000 IT. Security breaches, outages, and overall chaos. It’s going to get much worse.What can we do about it? Whether or not Google sees itself as a giant MIT or CalTech lab working on cool “scientific” consumer stuff, programming is the same, and Google (Facebook, Twitter, Netflix, etc.) inventions can and should be adapted for the enterprise technology. It can only be done by people who spent a good portion of their career in corporate IT due to the aforementioned attention span issue.The freshest best of breed business process automation technology dates to 1999: Salesforce. And IMO it is just a meticulous optimization and refinement of the age-old Oracle Forms. Remember where Marc Benioff worked before he founded Salesforce.Developing the 21st Century enterprise tech is not rocket science. It is largely the art of putting together already existing pieces, though in a very unorthodox manner, foreign to all current approaches, that cater to man-hour happy Great IT Consulting Food Chain making its money on bloated bodyshop and “offshore” headcounts.Bashing those parasites is pointless.
